summary.para: Wraps the AWS-CLI with methods for common operations.
summary.note: The class methods require that the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID and AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY environment variables be already set with the required AWS credentials.

member.returns: true when the exception is transient.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.AwsCli.S3Upload(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Uploads a file from the local workstation to S3.
member.param: The source file path.
The target S3 URI. This may be either an s3://BUCKET/KEY or a https://s3.REGION.amazonaws.com/BUCKET/KEY URI referencing an S3 bucket and key.
Optionally indicates that the target content encoding should be set to gzip.

param.name: metadata
param.para: Optionally specifies HTTP metadata headers to be returned when the object is downloaded from S3. This formatted as as comma separated a list of key/value pairs like:

note.para: AWS supports system as well as custom headers. System headers include standard HTTP headers such as Content-Type and Content-Encoding. Custom headers are required to include the x-amz-meta- prefix.

You don't need to specify the x-amz-meta- prefix for setting custom headers; the AWS-CLI detects custom header names and adds the prefix automatically. This method will strip the prefix if present before calling the AWS-CLI to ensure the prefix doesn't end up being duplicated.

member.param: Optionally grant the upload public read access.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.AwsCli.S3Upload(System.IO.Stream,System.String,System.Boolean,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Uploads the contents of a stream to an S3 bucket.
member.param: The input stream.
The target S3 URI. This may be either an s3://BUCKET/KEY or a https://s3.REGION.amazonaws.com/BUCKET/KEY URI referencing an S3 bucket and key.
Optionally indicates that the target content encoding should be set to gzip.

param.name: metadata
param.para: Optionally specifies HTTP metadata headers to be returned when the object is downloaded from S3. This formatted as as comma separated a list of key/value pairs like:

note.para: AWS supports system as well as custom headers. System headers include standard HTTP headers such as Content-Type and Content-Encoding. Custom headers are required to include the x-amz-meta- prefix.

You don't need to specify the x-amz-meta- prefix for setting custom headers; the AWS-CLI detects custom header names and adds the prefix automatically. This method will strip the prefix if present before calling the AWS-CLI to ensure the prefix doesn't end up being duplicated.

member.param: Optionally grant the upload public read access.

member.summary: Uploads text to an S3 bucket.

The target S3 URI. This may be either an s3://BUCKET/KEY or a https://s3.REGION.amazonaws.com/BUCKET/KEY URI referencing an S3 bucket and key.

param.name: metadata
param.para: Optionally specifies HTTP metadata headers to be returned when the object is downloaded from S3. This formatted as as comma separated a list of key/value pairs like:

note.para: AWS supports system as well as custom headers. System headers include standard HTTP headers such as Content-Type and Content-Encoding. Custom headers are required to include the x-amz-meta- prefix.

You don't need to specify the x-amz-meta- prefix for setting custom headers; the AWS-CLI detects custom header names and adds the prefix automatically. This method will strip the prefix if present before calling the AWS-CLI to ensure the prefix doesn't end up being duplicated.

member.param: Optionally grant the upload public read access.
Optionally specifies the text encoding. This defaults to .

member.summary: Downloads a file from S3 as a byte array.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.AwsCli.S3UploadMultiPart(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int64,System.Boolean,System.Action{System.Int64})

summary.para: Uploads a file in multiple parts from the local workstation to S3, returning the details. required by and to actually download the entire file. The URI to the uploaded details is also returned.
See the remarks for details about how this works.

member.param: Path to the file being uploaded.

param.name: targetFolderUri
param.para: The target S3 URI structured like https://s3.REGION.amazonaws.com/BUCKET/... URI referencing an S3 bucket and the optional folder where the file's download information and parts will be uploaded.
param.note: The s3:// URI scheme is not supported.

member.param: Optionally specifies the download file version.
Optionally overrides the download file name specified by to initialize .
Optionally overrides the download file name specified by to initialize .
This method creates a file named [.md5] with the MD5 hash for the entire uploaded file by default. You may override this behavior by passing =true.
Optionally overrides the maximum part size (defailts to 100 MiB).
Optionally grant the upload public read access.
Optional action called as the file is uploaded, passing the long percent complete.
member.returns: The information as well as the URI to the uploaded manifest.

remarks.para: This method works by splitting the file into parts no larger than bytes each and the uploading these parts to the specified bucket and path along with a file holding information describing the download and its constituent parts. This information includes details about the download including the overall MD5 and size as well records describing each part including their URIs, sizes and MD5.

The details returned include all of the information required by and
to actually download the entire file and the URI returned references these msame details as uploaded to S3.
You'll need to pass as the path to the file being uploaded and as the S3 location where the download information and the file parts will be uploaded. may use with the https:// or s3:// URI scheme.

By default the uploaded file and parts names will be based on the filename part of , but this can be overridden via . The information for the file will be uploaded as FILENAME.manifest and the parts will be written to a subfolder named FILENAME.parts. For example, uploading a large file named myfile.json to https://s3.uswest.amazonaws.com/mybucket will result S3 file layout like:
remarks.code: https://s3.uswest.amazonaws.com/mybucket myfile.json.manifest myfile.json.parts/ part-0000 part-0001 part-0002 ...
remarks.para: The URI returned in this case will be https://s3.uswest.amazonaws.com/mybucket/myfile.json.manifest.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.AwsCli.S3Remove(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Removes one S3 objects.
member.param: The target S3 URI or prefix for the object(s) to be removed. This may be either an s3://BUCKET[/KEY] or a https://s3.REGION.amazonaws.com/BUCKET[/KEY] URI referencing an S3 bucket and key. Note that the key is optional which means that all objects in the bucket are eligible for removal.
Optionally indicates specifies a folder prefix and that all objects within the folder are eligble for removal.
Optionally specifies a pattern specifying the objects to be removed.
Optionally specifies a pattern specifying objects to be excluded from removal.

member.name: T:Neon.Deployment.GitHub
member.summary: Implements common GitHub operations via the GitHub REST API.

remarks.para: To use this class, first call to load the necessary credentials from 1Password and the call the desired APIs. When you're done, it's a good practice to call .
remarks.note: This class currently requires that the GITHUB_PAT (personal access token) and GITHUB_LOGIN variables be available via 1Password for the current user. We need GITHUB_LOGIN right now so we can login and screen-scrap the GitHub website for package operations that don't have REST endpoints yet.

member.name: P:Neon.Deployment.GitHub.AccessToken
member.summary: Returns the GitHub PAT (personal access token) or null.

member.summary: Returns the GitHub user credentials or null.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.GitHub.GetCredentials
member.summary: Retrieves the necessary credentials from 1Password when necessary and caches them locally as well as in environment variables.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.GitHub.ClearCredentials
member.summary: Clears any cached credentials.

member.name: T:Neon.Deployment.GitHubReleaseApi
member.summary: Used to publish and manage GitHub releases.

remarks.note: This API doesn't currently support modifying assets of of published releases although GitHub does support this. We may add this functionality in the future.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.GitHubReleaseApi.#ctor
member.summary: Internal constructor.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.GitHubReleaseApi.Create(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a GitHub release.
member.param: Identifies the target repo.
Specifies the tag to be referenced by the release.
Optionally specifies the release name (defaults to ).
Optionally specifies the markdown formatted release notes.
Optionally indicates that the release won't be published immediately.
Optionally indicates that the release is not production ready.
Optionally identifies the branch to be tagged. This defaults to master or main when either of those branches are already present.

remarks.para: If the doesn't already exist in the repo, this method will tag the latest commit on the specified or else the defailt branch in the target repo and before creating the release.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.GitHubReleaseApi.Update(System.String,Octokit.Release,Octokit.ReleaseUpdate)
member.summary: Updates a GitHub release.
member.param: Identifies the target repository.
Specifies the release being updated.
Specifies the revisions.

remarks.para: To update a release, you'll first need to:

list.item:
Obtain a referencing the target release returned from
or by listing or getting releases.
Make your changes to the release update.
Call , passing the original release along with the update.

member.summary: Deletes a GitHub release.

The target release.

remarks.note: This fails silently if the release doesn't exist.

members.member:
Uploads a multi-part download to a release and then publishes the release.
Identifies the target repository. The target release. Path to the file being uploaded. The download version. Optionally overrides the download file name specified by to initialize . Optionally overrides the download file name specified by to initialize .
This method creates a file named [.md5] with the MD5 hash for the entire uploaded file by default. You may override this behavior by passing =true.
Optionally overrides the maximum part size (defailts to 100 MiB).d The .
The release passed must be unpublished and you may upload other assets before calling this.
Take care that any assets already published have names that won't conflict with the asset part names, which will be formatted like: part-##

member.returns: The path to the downloaded file.
member.exception: Thrown when the download is corrupt.
Thrown for network errors.
Thrown for HTTP network errors.
Thrown when the operation was cancelled.

remarks.para: This method downloads the file specified by to the folder specified, creating the folder first when required. The file will be downloaded in parts, where each part will be validated by comparing the part's MD5 hash (when present) with the computed value. The output file will be named and the overall MD5 hash will also be saved using the same file name but adding the .md5 extension.

This method will continue downloading a partially downloaded file. This works by validating the already downloaded parts against their MD5 hashes and then continuing part downloads after the last valid part. Nothing will be downloaded when the existing file is fully formed.
remarks.note: The target files (output and MD5) will be deleted when download appears to be corrupt.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.DeploymentHelper.DownloadMultiPartAsync(System.String,System.String,Neon.Deployment.DownloadProgressDelegate,System.TimeSpan,Neon.Retry.IRetryPolicy,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Asynchronously downloads and assembles a multi-part file as specified by a .
member.param: The URI for the source URI holding the details as JSON.
The target file path.
Optionally specifies an action to be called with the the percentage downloaded.
Optionally specifies the HTTP download timeout for each part (defaults to 10 minutes).
Optionally specifies the retry policy. This defaults to a reasonable policy.
Optionally specifies the operation cancellation token.
member.returns: The path to the downloaded file.
member.exception: Thrown when the download is corrupt.
Thrown for network errors.
Thrown for HTTP network errors.
Thrown when the operation was cancelled.
Thrown when the object retrieved from doesn't have the content type.

remarks.para: This method downloads the file specified by to the folder specified, creating the folder first when required. The file will be downloaded in parts, where each part will be validated by comparing the part's MD5 hash (when present) with the computed value. The output file will be named and the overall MD5 hash will also be saved using the same file name but adding the .md5 extension.

This method will continue downloading a partially downloaded file. This works by validating the already downloaded parts against their MD5 hashes and then continuing part downloads after the last valid part. Nothing will be downloaded when the existing file is fully formed.
remarks.note: The target files (output and MD5) will be deleted when download appears to be corrupt.

summary.para: The Neon.Deployment library includes utility classes for managing deployments for CI/CD.
summary.note: These classes are not entirely general purpose at this point. neonFORGE maintainers are currently using this for CI/CD for opensource and private neonFORGE related projects. We may make these more generic in the future.

member.name: T:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword
member.summary: Wraps the 1Password CLI.

member.name: T:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.OnePasswordStatus
member.summary: Unfortunately, the 1Password CLI doesn't appear to return specific exit codes detailing the for specific error yet. We're going to hack this by examining the response text.

member.name: F:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.OnePasswordStatus.OK
member.summary: The operation was successful.

member.name: F:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.OnePasswordStatus.SessionExpired
member.summary: The session token has expired.

member.name: F:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.OnePasswordStatus.Other
member.summary: Unspecified error.

member.name: P:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.Signedin
member.summary: Returns true if the class is signed-in.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.Configure(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Configures and signs into 1Password for the first time on a machine. This must be called once before will work.
member.param: Specifies the 1Password signin address.
Specifies the 1Password shorthand name to use for the account (e.g. "sally@neonforge.com").
The 1Password secret key for the account.
Specified the master 1Password.
Specifies the default 1Password vault.

remarks.para: Typically, you'll first call once for a workstation to configure the signin address and 1Password secret key during manual configuration. The account shorthand name used for that operation can then be used thereafter for calls to which don't require the additional information.

This two-stage process enhances security because both the master password and secret key are required to authenticate and the only time the secret key will need to be presented for the full login which will typically done manually once. 1Password securely stores the secret key on the workstation and it will never need to be present as plaintext again on the machine.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.Signin(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Signs into 1Password using just the account, master password, and default vault. You'll typically call this rather than which also requires the signin address as well as the secret key.
member.param: The account's shorthand name (e.g. (e.g. "sally@neonforge.com").
The master password.
The default vault.

remarks.para: Typically, you'll first call once for a workstation to configure the signin address and 1Password secret key during manual configuration. The account shorthand name used for that operation can then be used thereafter for calls to this method which don't require the additional information.

This two-stage process enhances security because both the master password and secret key are required to authenticate and the only time the secret key will need to be presented for the full login which will typically done manually once. 1Password securely stores the secret key on the workstation and it will never need to be present as plaintext again on the machine.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.OnePassword.Signout

member.name: T:Neon.Deployment.ProfileServer
member.summary: Implements a named-pipe based server that will be used to receive requests from . This server listens on a named pipe and only allows connections from other processes running on behalf of the current user.

remarks.note: This class currently supports only Windows.
remarks.para: This server implements simple string based request response protocol, where the client writes a line of text with the request and the server sends a line of text as the response. Only one request/response per client pipe connection is allowed. Requests are formatted like:
where COMMAND is one of the values below with one or more comma separated arguments formatted as name/value pairs. Response lines are formatted like:

where the "OK:" and "OK-JSON:" prefixes indicate that the operation succeeded. Some operations like password or value lookups simply return the request result as the string after the prefix. Future operations may return a JSON result.

The ERROR[STATUS]: prefix indicates an error occured. STATUS identifies the specific error and the response will typically include an message describing what happened. The supported status codes are defined by .
Here are the supported commands:

description.para: This requests a password from 1Password by name and vault, which is optional and defaults to the user name as defined by the userVault Neon Assistant setting. The password is returned as the response.
masterpassword is optional. This is passed in circumstances where the caller already knows the master password, such as for fully automated CI/CD operations.

This requests a secret value from 1Password by name and vault, which is optional and defaults to the user name as defined by the userVault Neon Assistant setting. The value is returned as the response.
masterpassword is optional. This is passed in circumstances where the caller already knows the master password, such as for fully automated CI/CD operations.
This requests a profile value the user's local profile by NAME. he value is returned as the response.

This submits an arbitrary operation to the server, passing arguments and returning a result string. We're using this to workaround some limitations with the GHCR REST API by locating the implementation in neon-assistant.
We may use this in the future for other neon-assistant interactions.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.ProfileServer.ParseSecretName(System.String)

summary.para: Parses a secret name by extracting the name and property components. secret names can be formatted like: NAME or NAME[PROPERTY].
summary.note: When the property syntax passed is malformed, we're just going to return the entire input string as the name rather than throwing an exception here. This will probably result in a failed lookup which will be reported to the user who will have a good chance then of figuring out what happened.

member.param: The secret name.
member.returns: An anonymous structure including the name and property (if specified).

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.ProfileServer.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32)
member.param: The server named pipe name. This defaults to .
Optionally specifies the number of threads to create to handle inbound requests. This defaults to 10.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.ProfileServer.Start
member.summary: Starts the server. You should call this after configuring the handler callbacks.
member.exception: Thrown if any of the handlers are not initialized.

member.name: P:Neon.Deployment.ProfileServer.GetIsReady
member.summary: Optional callback used to determine whether the profile server implementation is ready for requests. The handler returns null when ready or a error to be returned to the caller.

summary.para: Callback that retrieves a profile value. The parameters is the profile value name.
summary.note: This must be initalized before calling .

summary.para: Callback that retrieves a secret password. The parameters are the secret name optional vault and master password.
summary.note: This must be initalized before calling .

summary.para: Callback that retrieves a secret value. The parameters are the secret name optional vault, and master password.
summary.note: This must be initalized before calling .

summary.para: Callback that performs an arbitrary operation.
summary.note: This must be initalized before calling .

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.ProfileServer.ServerThread(System.Object)
member.summary: Handles incoming client connections on a background thread.
member.param: Passes as the index into the [pipes] array this thread will use for its server side pipe.

member.name: T:Neon.Deployment.XenServer
member.summary: XenServer/XCP-ng related deployment utilities.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.XenServer.IsRunning(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether a specific XenServer/XCP-ng host machine is running by logging into it.
member.param: Specifies the IP address or hostname for the target XenServer host machine.
Specifies the username to be used to connect to the host.
Specifies the host password.
member.returns: true if the host machine is running.

member.name: M:Neon.Deployment.XenServer.RemoveVMs(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Connects to a XenServer/XCP-ng host and removes any VMs matching the name or file wildcard pattern, forceably shutting the VMs down when necessary. Note that the VM's drives will also be removed.
member.param: Specifies the IP address or hostname for the target XenServer host machine.
Specifies the username to be used to connect to the host.
Specifies the host password.
Specifies the VM name or pattern including '*' or '?' wildcards to be used to remove VMs.
